population_specificity: Piglets (1 to 9 weeks old, tested starting at 12 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of maltodextrin crosslinked with citric acid as an encapsulating material for mushroom extracts in improving stability and bioactivity in yogurt.
results_summary: Thermally treated microencapsulated extracts with maltodextrin and citric acid showed higher antioxidant activity over time compared to free or untreated forms, demonstrating effective protection and functionalization of yogurt.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or food product study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of maltodextrin-based nanoparticles for enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) in treating disorders associated with tyrosine hydroxylase (TH) dysfunction, particularly Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The study found that TH-loaded maltodextrin nanoparticles maintained enzyme stability and activity, facilitated neuronal uptake, and increased intracellular L-Dopa synthesis, suggesting promise for ERT in dopamine-deficient disorders.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and potential neurological applications, e.g., Parkinson's disease).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of partially replacing maltodextrin with native agave fructans on the characteristics of spray-dried pineapple and mango powder.
results_summary: Increasing maltodextrin concentration and inlet temperature reduced moisture content, water activity (aw), and solubility. Adding more than 2% agave fructans increased aw, moisture, hygroscopicity, wettability, and solubility, but storage stability remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Spray-dried pineapple and mango powder (in vitro study, no human subjects).
study_duration: Not specified (likely a single processing experiment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the safety of Steady-fiber granule (SFG), which contains resistant maltodextrin, by evaluating genotoxicity and 28-day oral toxicity.
results_summary: SFG showed no mutagenicity, clastogenic effects, or genotoxicity in bacterial, cell, and mouse tests. A 28-day oral toxicity study in rats revealed no adverse effects on mortality, body weight, organ weights, behavior, hematology, clinical biochemistry, or histopathology.
population_specificity: Male and female rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of replacing sucrose with a stevioside-maltodextrin mixture on the physicochemical properties of Naanberenji cookies.
results_summary: The study found that replacing sucrose with stevioside-maltodextrin increased hardness and reduced browning in the cookies, with a 25% replacement level being most similar to the control. Caloric content decreased by 7.27%, and sugar consumption was reduced by 23.06% at this level.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on cookie properties, not human subjects).
effective_dosage: 25%, 50%, 75%, and 100% replacement levels of sucrose with stevioside-maltodextrin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the consistency stability of water thickened with maltodextrin, xanthan gum, and potassium chloride over time for patients with dysphagia.
results_summary: The study found that thickened water maintained its consistency for at least 12 hours, with slight increases in consistency after 10 hours. Changes in consistency occurred after 24 hours for mildly thick preparations and after 48 hours for moderately thick preparations.
population_specificity: Patients with dysphagia and airway aspiration.
effective_dosage: 1.2 g (nectar), 2.4 g (honey), and 3.6 g (pudding) of thickener per 100 ml of water.
study_duration: Measurements taken hourly for 12 hours and every 24 hours for 96 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of maltodextrin/ascorbic acid treatment on wound healing, both in vitro and in vivo, focusing on collagen turnover and inflammation modulation.
results_summary: Maltodextrin/ascorbic acid improved wound repair by increasing collagen turnover, TGF-β1 expression, and gelatinase activity while reducing TIMP-1. In venous leg ulcers, it reduced microorganism populations and enhanced wound closure compared to zinc oxide, with better tissue architecture and granulation.
population_specificity: Patients with venous leg ulcers and in vitro fibroblast models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a controlled-release nateglinide formulation using maltodextrin as a coated carrier to improve oral bioavailability and efficacy compared to the marketed formulation.
results_summary: The maltodextrin-coated provesicular formulation (F4) showed improved in vitro drug release, higher intestinal permeation, and significantly reduced blood glucose levels in diabetic rats compared to the control and marketed formulation.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of digestion-resistant maltodextrin (RMD) on colonic transit time and defecation characteristics in healthy adults.
results_summary: RMD significantly reduced total and segmental colonic transit times, increased stool volume by 56%, and improved stool consistency compared to baseline and placebo, with no reported adverse effects.
population_specificity: 66 healthy adult volunteers (32 men) without a daily defecation habit.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the stability and efficacy of maltodextrin-encapsulated grape skin phenolics as a sustainable coloring agent and health-promoting compound in apple puree under heat treatment and storage conditions.
results_summary: The study found that maltodextrin-encapsulated phenolics retained 100% of monomeric anthocyanins after mild heat treatment (3 D), decreasing to 72% under intense heating (14 D). The fortified puree exhibited a two-fold higher reducing capacity compared to unfortified apple puree, demonstrating enhanced health-promoting properties.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or food matrix study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether maltodextrin enhances the efficacy of electrochemical scaffolds (e-scaffolds) in reducing biofilm cell densities of *Acinetobacter baumannii* and *Staphylococcus aureus*.
results_summary: The study found that maltodextrin significantly increased the efficacy of e-scaffolds, achieving maximum log reductions of 8.27 for *A. baumannii* and 4.71 for *S. aureus* biofilms at 10 mM and 30 mM concentrations, respectively, along with a ~55% decrease in biofilm surface coverage.
population_specificity: *Acinetobacter baumannii* and *Staphylococcus aureus* biofilms in vitro.
effective_dosage: 10 mM for *A. baumannii*, 30 mM for *S. aureus*.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of resistant maltodextrin (RMD) on reproductive function and metabolic control in streptozotocin-nicotinamide-induced type 2 diabetic male rats.
results_summary: RMD supplementation improved plasma glucose control, reduced insulin resistance, and restored testosterone levels and spermatogenesis in diabetic rats. Higher doses (5×) also reversed protein deficiencies related to steroidogenesis and reduced germ cell apoptosis.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-nicotinamide-induced type 2 diabetic male rats.
effective_dosage: 1.2 g, 2.4 g, and 6.0 g per 100 g diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining maltodextrin with vancomycin enhances effectiveness against Staphylococcus aureus biofilms compared to either treatment alone.
results_summary: Maltodextrin altered biofilm structure and, when combined with vancomycin, significantly enhanced treatment effectiveness. Higher maltodextrin concentrations reduced vancomycin diffusion but increased osmotic effects, optimizing treatment conditions.
population_specificity: Staphylococcus aureus biofilms in a flat plate flow cell reactor.
interactions: Interaction with vancomycin noted (reduced diffusion but enhanced osmotic effect).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of maltodextrin gel (MD) and silver alginate sponge (AG) in treating tracheostomy-related wounds in children.
results_summary: The study found that MD and AG treatments led to complete epithelialization of all wounds, with an average treatment duration of 12.8 days and no reported adverse effects.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (ages 0.25-15.6 years) with tracheostomy-related wounds.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate maltodextrin-based proniosomes as a controlled delivery system for nateglinide in diabetic therapy.
results_summary: The maltodextrin-based proniosomal formulation significantly enhanced the plasma concentration and absorption rate of nateglinide compared to the pure drug, suggesting improved bioavailability and potential for effective diabetic therapy.
population_specificity: New Zealand albino male rabbits

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the metabolizable and net energy values of resistant maltodextrin (RM) and its effects on fecal microbiota and macronutrient excretion.
results_summary: The study found that RM increased fecal energy, nitrogen, carbohydrate excretion, and fecal bulk, while also promoting the growth of specific gut microbial populations. Both doses of RM showed significant effects, with higher doses leading to greater changes.
population_specificity: 14 men
effective_dosage: 25 g/d RM + 25 g/d maltodextrin and 50 g/d RM + 0 g/d maltodextrin

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the maximum single dose of resistant maltodextrin (Fibersol-2) that does not induce transitory diarrhea in healthy adults.
results_summary: The study found that the maximum non-effective single dose was 1.0 g/kg bw for men and >1.1 g/kg bw for women, with only mild and transient gastrointestinal symptoms reported at higher doses.
population_specificity: 10 healthy adults (5 men and 5 women).
effective_dosage: 0.7, 0.8, 0.9, 1.0, and 1.1 g/kg body weight, administered once per week.
study_duration: Each dose was separated by 1 week, with no total study duration specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if adding hydrolyzed protein to a carbohydrate-based drink (containing maltodextrin) could reduce inflammatory response and hospital length of stay in preoperative patients.
results_summary: The intervention group, which consumed a beverage with maltodextrin and hydrolyzed pea protein, had a significantly shorter postoperative hospital stay and lower inflammatory markers compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing gastrointestinal resection due to cancer.
effective_dosage: 400 mL the night before and 200 mL 3 h before surgery (containing 79% maltodextrin).
study_duration: Administered once the night before and once 3 h before surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of resistant maltodextrin (RMD) in improving risk factors associated with metabolic syndrome in humans.
results_summary: The study found that RMD significantly reduced waist circumference, visceral fat area, fasting blood glucose, HOMA-R, and serum triacylglycerol in subjects with metabolic syndrome. The total number of metabolic syndrome risk factors decreased more in the RMD group compared to the placebo group.
population_specificity: Thirty subjects with metabolic syndrome.
effective_dosage: 9 g of RMD taken three times daily at mealtimes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of maltodextrin, amylase, and their combination on the physicochemical, functional, and antioxidant properties of spray-dried purple sweet potato flour.
results_summary: Maltodextrin-treated flours showed higher antioxidant capacity compared to amylase-treated flours but lower anthocyanin and phenolic content. Maltodextrin increased the glass transition temperature and improved certain functional properties like water solubility.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or food product study, no human subjects mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety of hydrogenated resistant maltodextrin through acute and subchronic toxicity studies in rats and an acute no-effect level study in humans.
results_summary: The study found no mutagenicity or lethal toxicity in rats, with transient osmotic effects at high doses. The NOAEL was 10 g/kg (acute) and 5.0 g/kg/day (subchronic) in rats, and the acute no-effect level for diarrhea was 0.8 g/kg (men) and >1.0 g/kg (women) in humans.
population_specificity: Rats (acute and subchronic toxicity) and healthy adult humans (acute no-effect level).
effective_dosage: 10 g/kg (acute rat), 5 g/kg/day (subchronic rat), 0.8 g/kg (men), >1.0 g/kg (women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate maltodextrin as a novel excipient for preparing orally disintegrating tablets (ODTs) of meclizine, focusing on balancing disintegration time and tablet hardness.
results_summary: Maltodextrin enabled rapid disintegration (30-40 s) with acceptable hardness (1-3 kg), particularly after post-compression conditioning. Wet granulation-conditioning outperformed direct compression, avoiding issues like the patch effect. DSC and X-ray analysis suggested glass-elastic deformation contributed to maltodextrin's hardening effect.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro/ex vivo study, no human participants mentioned).
effective_dosage: Not specified (concentrations studied but exact dosages not detailed).
study_duration: Not specified (conditioning at 40°C and 75% relative humidity, but duration not clearly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding protein and amino acids to a maltodextrin and galactose recovery drink improved post-exercise liver and muscle glycogen repletion compared to maltodextrin and galactose alone.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in liver or muscle glycogen recovery between the maltodextrin-galactose (MD-GAL) and maltodextrin-galactose-protein+amino acids (MD-GAL-PRO+AA) groups, though the MD-GAL group had a higher rate of muscle glycogen repletion. The increased insulin response in the MD-GAL-PRO+AA group compensated for the lower maltodextrin content but did not enhance glycogen recovery.
population_specificity: Seven trained male cyclists.
effective_dosage: MD-GAL (0.9 g MD/kg body mass per hour and 0.3 g GAL/kg body mass per hour); MD-GAL-PRO+AA (0.5 g MD/kg body mass per hour, 0.3 g GAL/kg body mass per hour, 0.4 g whey protein hydrolysate plus l-leucine and l-phenylalanine/kg body mass per hour), ingested every 30 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the prebiotic effects, gastrointestinal tolerance, and fecal characteristics of resistant maltodextrin compared to normal maltodextrin in free-living humans.
results_summary: Resistant maltodextrin increased fecal Bifidobacterium populations, altered bacterial populations, and shifted SCFA proportions toward butyrate, with minor gastrointestinal effects. It was well-tolerated and showed favorable fermentation characteristics.
population_specificity: Free-living humans (n = 38)
effective_dosage: 15 g maltodextrin, 7.5 g maltodextrin + 7.5 g resistant maltodextrin, or 15 g resistant maltodextrin daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a method for efficient maltodextrin conversion to alpha-D-glucose-1-phosphate using a fusion enzyme system.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that 83% of maltodextrin phosphorylase activity was retained in active inclusion bodies, which were easily isolated and used for repetitive batch conversion with only 10% activity loss after ten cycles.
population_specificity: In vitro study using Escherichia coli BL21 for enzyme expression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the health effects of resistant maltodextrin with synthetic inulin and clofibrate, particularly on lipid profiles and metabolic parameters in rats fed a high-fat diet.
results_summary: Resistant maltodextrin reduced liver triacylglycerol and total cholesterol levels in rats on a high-fat diet, similar to synthetic inulin, but did not show effects on portal plasma glucose or adiponectin levels as inulin did.
population_specificity: Rats fed a high-fat, high-sucrose (cafeteria) diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the time-course of metabolism and energy availability from resistant maltodextrin (RMD) by modeling respiratory gases after a single oral dose.
results_summary: The study found that 17% of RMD was available carbohydrate (AC) and 40% was fermentable carbohydrate (FC), with mean energy values of 7.3 kJ ME/g and 6.3 kJ NME/g. The fiber fraction of RMD provided 5.2 kJ ME/g and 4.1 kJ NME/g.
population_specificity: Seventeen healthy adults (13 males, 4 females; aged 25-46 years).
effective_dosage: Single oral dose (specific amount not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the enzymatic properties and expression regulation of the alpha-glucosidase MalL in Bacillus subtilis, particularly its ability to hydrolyze maltodextrins and related substrates.
results_summary: The study found that MalL hydrolyzes various disaccharides and maltodextrins up to maltohexaose but not longer chains. Its expression is induced by maltose, starch, amylose, and glycogen, and it shows temporal variation with a second induction in the stationary growth phase.
population_specificity: Bacillus subtilis (bacterial model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the structural interactions of acarbose with maltodextrin phosphorylase (MalP) to understand substrate selectivity and enzyme targeting.
results_summary: The study found that acarbose binds to MalP in a conformation close to its minimum free energy state, occupying specific sub-sites (+1 to +4) and revealing conserved tyrosine interactions. This structural insight explains MalP's preference for pentasaccharide substrates and highlights acarbose's flexibility in targeting different carbohydrate enzymes.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro crystallographic study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether acarbose, due to its structural similarity to maltotetraose, is recognized as a substrate by the maltose/maltodextrin system of Escherichia coli.
results_summary: Acarbose competitively inhibited maltose uptake in E. coli with a Ki of 1.1 microM and was transported by maltose-grown cells, indicating substrate recognition. However, acarbose could not be utilized as a carbon source due to poor interaction with key enzymes (MalQ and MalZ).
population_specificity: Escherichia coli K-12

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of maltodextrin-electrolyte solutions (with and without added nutrients) against the WHO oral rehydration solution in reversing cholera toxin-induced intestinal water secretion.
results_summary: All three solutions reversed cholera toxin-induced water secretion to net absorption, with the maltodextrin-electrolyte solution showing significantly greater water absorption than the WHO solution. No significant differences were observed in net sodium, potassium, or chloride fluxes between the maltodextrin-electrolyte and WHO solutions.
population_specificity: Rat intestine (secreting rat intestine model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a reduced-osmolarity maltodextrin-based ORS had similar benefits to a reduced-osmolarity glucose-based ORS for treating acute noncholera diarrhea in children and to assess the effect of sugar malabsorption on efficacy.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in treatment outcomes between standard ORS and maltodextrin-based ORS. High stool output was associated with prolonged diarrhea, elevated serum sodium, and increased need for intravenous infusion, but this was unrelated to the type of ORS used. Reduced-osmolarity maltodextrin-based ORS did not show benefits over standard ORS, likely due to malabsorbed sugars raising intraluminal osmolarity.
population_specificity: 90 boys aged 3-24 months with acute noncholera diarrhea and moderate dehydration.
effective_dosage: Maltodextrin 50 g/l in the ORS solution.
study_duration: Duration of diarrhea (median 15-33 hours, depending on stool output).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of immobilized glucoamylase (GA) in hydrolyzing maltodextrin in a fluidized bed reactor (FBR) and assess the enzyme's stability and activity under process conditions.
results_summary: The study found that immobilizing GA on magnetic microparticles improved enzyme stability, reduced the deactivation rate constant, and maintained high activity (71% remaining activity) during continuous hydrolysis of maltodextrin. After two weeks of operation, the immobilized GA retained 96% of its initial activity, demonstrating robust performance in producing high-conversion syrup.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study using a fluidized bed reactor system).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of an improved oral rehydration solution (ORS) containing maltodextrin, glycine, and glycyl-glycine versus standard ORS in treating acute watery diarrhea in young children.
results_summary: The improved ORS with maltodextrin did not significantly reduce stool volume but showed greater weight gain in children, though this difference was only statistically significant at 24 hours. No significant differences were observed in rotavirus-positive cases between the two ORS groups.
population_specificity: Male children aged 6-35 months with acute watery diarrhea for less than 48 hours before hospitalization.
effective_dosage: 20 g maltodextrin per ORS formulation (exact frequency not specified).
study_duration: Duration of intervention not explicitly stated, but outcomes were measured at 24 hours and beyond.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of an improved oral rehydration solution (ORS) containing maltodextrin, glycine, and glycyl-glycine against the standard WHO ORS in treating dehydration caused by acute watery diarrhea.
results_summary: The improved ORS with maltodextrin did not reduce stool volume in cholera patients and even increased it, but it led to greater weight gain in cholera patients during specific periods. Non-cholera patients treated with the improved ORS showed reduced stool volumes during the 6-24 hour period.
population_specificity: 108 male adults (mean age 33 ± 1.7 years) with severe dehydration due to acute watery diarrhea, including 85 with cholera.
effective_dosage: 20 g maltodextrin (replacing glucose) in the improved ORS formulation.
study_duration: Intervention lasted until discharge, with key outcomes measured at 6 hours, second day, and discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of an oral rehydration solution containing maltodextrin (GGG-ORS) against a standard glucose-based ORS in treating acute gastroenteritis with moderate dehydration.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in stool output or duration of diarrhea between the two groups. However, the GGG-ORS group showed higher urine output and weight gain in the initial 6 hours, though these differences did not persist beyond that period.
population_specificity: Children aged 3 months to 3 years with acute gastroenteritis and moderate dehydration.
effective_dosage: Not specified (osmolality of GGG-ORS was 305 mOsm/l).
study_duration: Initial 6 hours with follow-up until rehydration was achieved.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of a maltodextrin-containing ORS solution with the WHO-recommended glucose-ORS solution in treating mild to moderate dehydration in children with acute diarrhea.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in stool output, ORS intake, or recovery duration between the maltodextrin and glucose-ORS groups. Hematocrit and serum electrolyte values were also similar, suggesting maltodextrin-ORS offers no advantage over WHO-ORS.
population_specificity: Children aged 4-36 months with acute diarrhea causing mild to moderate dehydration.
study_duration: Duration of recovery ranged from 1-9 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Bifidobacterium animalis subsp lactis HN019 in maltodextrin improved bowel movements compared to a maltodextrin placebo in individuals with functional constipation.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in the change of weekly complete spontaneous bowel movements (CSBMs) between the probiotic (HN019 in maltodextrin) and placebo (maltodextrin alone) groups, indicating maltodextrin did not enhance bowel function beyond placebo effects. Secondary outcomes, such as stool consistency and abdominal symptoms, also showed no notable differences.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers aged 18-70 with functional constipation (Rome III criteria), predominantly female (84.7%), and a mean BMI of 22.8.
effective_dosage: Maltodextrin placebo was administered once daily (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of creatine supplementation combined with maltodextrin on sleep quality in naturally menstruating females.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding maltodextrin's effects, focusing instead on the broader study design and creatine supplementation.
population_specificity: Naturally menstruating females.
effective_dosage: 5 g maltodextrin (combined with 5 g creatine) or 10 g maltodextrin (placebo) daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Bifidobacterium animalis subsp. lactis BLa80 in maltodextrin improves intestinal habits in adults with chronic constipation.
results_summary: The study found that the probiotic in maltodextrin significantly improved stool consistency (types 3 and 4 on the Bristol Scale) and reduced constipation symptoms compared to placebo, with statistically significant results at weeks 8 and 12. The proportion of constipated patients in the intervention group decreased over time, while it slightly increased in the placebo group.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18 and over with chronic constipation (type 1 or 2 stools on the Bristol Scale and/or fewer than three stools per week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of maltodextrin as a placebo compared to probiotic supplementation on necrotizing enterocolitis and mortality in extremely preterm infants.
results_summary: The abstract does not report specific results regarding maltodextrin's effects, as it was used as a placebo control in the study. The primary focus was on probiotic supplementation outcomes.
population_specificity: Extremely preterm infants (born before 28 weeks' gestational age) in Sweden and Denmark.
effective_dosage: 0.5 g maltodextrin powder diluted in 3 mL breastmilk per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether maltodextrin, used as a placebo, had any effect on muscle recovery, soreness, or performance compared to PEA supplementation following eccentric exercise.
results_summary: Maltodextrin, as a placebo, showed no significant effects on muscle strength, jump performance, soreness, or molecular markers of muscle damage, catabolism, or regeneration compared to PEA. The study found no discernible impact of maltodextrin on recovery outcomes.
population_specificity: 11 healthy male participants
study_duration: Single bout of exercise with measurements up to 120 hours post-exercise

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the ergogenic and metabolic effects of maltodextrin (a high GI carbohydrate) with other CHO sources during endurance exercise.
results_summary: Maltodextrin resulted in higher blood glucose levels compared to other supplements during the 100-minute protocol, but no ergogenic superiority was found between different CHO types in the 20-minute time trial.
population_specificity: 13 male cyclists
study_duration: 100-minute cycling protocol followed by a 20-minute time trial

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether maternal supplementation with maltodextrin (as a placebo) compared to prebiotics affects the risk of allergic outcomes in infants with hereditary risk.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in infant eczema or other allergic outcomes between the maltodextrin (placebo) and prebiotics groups, suggesting maltodextrin had no adverse effects but also no therapeutic benefits in this context.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with infants at hereditary risk of allergic disease (first-degree relative with medically diagnosed allergic disease).
study_duration: From less than 21 weeks' gestation until 6 months postnatal during lactation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare gastric residual volumes in morbidly obese diabetic patients after traditional fasting versus abbreviated fasting with a maltodextrin-containing drink.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in gastric residual volumes between traditional fasting and abbreviated fasting with maltodextrin, suggesting similar gastric emptying rates in both conditions. The results indicate that maltodextrin did not adversely affect gastric emptying in this population.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese type II diabetic patients (n=8, mean BMI 48.2 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 25 g (12.5%) maltodextrin in water, consumed 3 hours before measurement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a prebiotic supplement (GOS/FOS) against a placebo (maltodextrin) on maternal and infant gut microbiota.
results_summary: Maltodextrin was used as a placebo and showed no significant favorable modifications to maternal or infant gut microbiota compared to the prebiotic group. The placebo group exhibited lower Bifidobacteria abundance and higher Negativicutes in microbiota.
population_specificity: Pregnant women (<21 weeks' gestation) and their infants up to 12 months post-partum.
study_duration: From <21 weeks' gestation to six months post-partum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of maltodextrin (as a placebo) versus creatine supplementation on body composition and total body water measurements using different bioelectrical impedance devices.
results_summary: Maltodextrin was used as a placebo and showed no significant changes in body composition or total body water compared to creatine, which increased fat-free mass and total body water. The study did not report any specific effects of maltodextrin beyond its role as a control.
population_specificity: 13 male and 14 female subjects aged 18-22 years.
effective_dosage: 0.3 g/kg body weight (exact frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of maltodextrin (as a placebo) against a prebiotic supplement on upper respiratory and gastrointestinal symptoms in elite rugby players.
results_summary: The study found no significant adverse effects from maltodextrin, but it was used as a placebo and not directly evaluated for efficacy. The prebiotic group showed reduced symptom duration and severity compared to the maltodextrin group.
population_specificity: Elite rugby union players

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the effects of creatine monohydrate (CR) supplementation on body composition, performance, and cognitive function in female collegiate dancers.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results regarding Maltodextrin.
population_specificity: Female collegiate dancers

study_goal: The study aimed to evaluate the effects of multispecies probiotics mixed with fructooligosaccharides on body composition, antioxidant status, and gut microbiome composition in overweight and obese individuals.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Maltodextrin's effects.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese individuals aged 18-45 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of whey protein supplementation versus maltodextrin (as an isocaloric control) on glycemic control, muscle strength, functional tasks, and body composition in older adults with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Maltodextrin was used as a control and showed no significant difference compared to whey protein in muscle strength, functional tasks, glycemic control, or body composition. The study confirmed the safety of maltodextrin regarding renal function.
population_specificity: Older men (68.5 ± 11.5 years) with type 2 diabetes mellitus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of maltodextrin (as a placebo) versus creatine supplementation on functional capacity, strength, and muscle mass changes in stroke patients during hospitalization.
results_summary: The study did not report specific outcomes for maltodextrin alone, as it was used as a placebo control. The focus was on creatine supplementation, with no adverse effects or significant benefits attributed to maltodextrin.
population_specificity: Individuals with acute ischemic stroke during hospitalization.

study_goal: The researchers were comparing the effects of rhubarb extract (RE) supplementation to maltodextrin (placebo) on constipation symptoms in middle-aged volunteers.
results_summary: The study found that maltodextrin (placebo) did not improve stool frequency, consistency, or perceived transit issues compared to RE-treated groups.
population_specificity: Middle-aged volunteers (95% women, average age 58 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of maltodextrin as a placebo compared to white common bean extract (WCBE) on glucose metabolism and diabetic complications in type 2 diabetes patients.
results_summary: Maltodextrin was used as a placebo and showed inferior outcomes compared to WCBE, with slight decreases in nerve conduction velocity and no significant improvement in glucose metabolism or diabetic complications.
population_specificity: Ninety subjects with type 2 diabetes, later reduced to fifty-five for maintenance intervention.
effective_dosage: 1.5 g of maltodextrin as a placebo.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of maltodextrin (as a placebo) against aronia berry (poly)phenol extract on cardiometabolic health and gut microbiome in prehypertensive individuals.
results_summary: Maltodextrin, used as a placebo, showed no significant changes in blood pressure, endothelial function, or blood lipids compared to the aronia berry group. The study did not report any adverse effects specific to maltodextrin.
population_specificity: Prehypertensive middle-aged men and women (n=51 in the control group).
effective_dosage: Not specified (matched placebo to aronia berry extract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether maltodextrin, used as a placebo, had any effect on muscle force recovery or inflammatory cytokine concentrations after eccentric exercise compared to ketone monoester supplementation.
results_summary: Maltodextrin did not significantly differ from ketone monoester in attenuating muscle force decline or modulating inflammatory cytokine responses post-exercise, serving effectively as a neutral placebo in the study.
population_specificity: 16 healthy males and females (4 females in the maltodextrin group).
effective_dosage: Isocaloric maltodextrin placebo drinks, thrice daily (specific amount not detailed beyond isocaloric equivalence to 27g ketone monoester per dose).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of maternal prebiotic supplementation (galacto-oligosaccharides and fructo-oligosaccharides) against a placebo (maltodextrin) on infant allergic disease outcomes.
results_summary: The abstract does not report results, as it describes a study protocol rather than completed findings. Maltodextrin was used as a placebo control, but no effects or comparisons were detailed.
population_specificity: Pregnant women (18-20 weeks' gestation) with infants at high risk of allergic disease due to a first-degree relative with medically diagnosed allergies.
study_duration: From 18-20 weeks' gestation to six months post-partum.

study_goal: The study aimed to investigate the effects of resistance exercise and whey protein supplementation (alone and combined) on energy expenditure, substrate oxidation, and body composition in healthy older men.
results_summary: The study did not assess Maltodextrin; it focused on whey protein supplementation and resistance exercise, showing benefits in fat-free mass, metabolic rate, and fat mass reduction.
population_specificity: Healthy older men (mean age 67 ± 1 years, BMI 25.4 ± 0.4 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: Not mentioned (study focused on whey protein, not Maltodextrin).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether resistant dextrin supplementation could improve sleep and quality of life in obese women with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that resistant dextrin improved sleep and quality of life in obese women with type 2 diabetes, likely due to modulation of glycemia, metabolic endotoxemia, and reduced inflammation and HPA axis activity.
population_specificity: Obese female type 2 diabetic patients (n=76).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of maltodextrin (as a placebo) against sodium pyruvate on repeated sprint exercise performance and recovery in athletes.
results_summary: Maltodextrin was used as a placebo and showed no significant improvements in power output, ATP-PCr resynthesis, or acid-base balance compared to sodium pyruvate.
population_specificity: 14 male soccer athletes (aged 20±2 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of whey protein versus maltodextrin (placebo) on muscle mass, strength, and functional capacity in older individuals undergoing resistance training.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between the whey protein and maltodextrin groups in muscle strength, mass, or functional capacity improvements, suggesting maltodextrin did not hinder resistance training outcomes. Both groups showed similar increases in muscle thickness, lean mass, and functional performance over time.
population_specificity: Older individuals (60-80 years, male and female) undergoing resistance training.
effective_dosage: 20 g at breakfast + 20 g at dinner daily.

study_goal: The study did not investigate Maltodextrin; it focused on the effects of resistance exercise and whey protein supplementation in older adults.
results_summary: The study did not examine Maltodextrin; it found that resistance exercise improved muscle strength, fat-free mass, and physical function, while whey protein supplementation alone increased gait speed.
population_specificity: Healthy older men (mean age 67 years, BMI 25.5 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 12% carbohydrate beverage containing maltodextrin and sucrose could improve tackling technique, running performance, and perceived exertion during rugby league activity while maintaining gut comfort.
results_summary: The study found that the 12% CHO beverage effectively retained tackling technique, increased external responses (e.g., sprint performance), and reduced perceived exertion without causing significant gut discomfort. The supplement effect was statistically significant for several performance metrics, though interaction effects were limited.
population_specificity: 15 academy rugby league players
effective_dosage: 30 g maltodextrin and 30 g sucrose in 500 ml, ingested as a 250 ml bolus 15 minutes before activity
study_duration: Two bouts of rugby activity (duration not specified beyond the intervention timing)

study_goal: The researchers used maltodextrin as a placebo to compare against saffron supplementation and concurrent training in obese men with T2DM.
results_summary: Maltodextrin was used as a placebo and showed no significant effects on inflammatory markers or metabolic profiles compared to the active interventions. The study did not focus on evaluating maltodextrin's efficacy or safety.
population_specificity: Obese men with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM), aged 39 ± 5 years.
effective_dosage: Daily one pill (specific maltodextrin dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of Lycium barbarum polysaccharide (LBP) supplementation compared to a maltodextrin placebo in modulating gut microbiota for NAFLD patients.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding maltodextrin's effects, as it focuses on LBP's potential benefits and the study's design.
population_specificity: 50 patients with NAFLD confirmed by abdominal ultrasound, laboratory tests, and questionnaire surveys.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of black rice extract (BRE) versus maltodextrin (placebo) on obesity in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in anthropometric measures (weight, BMI, waist circumference, etc.) between the maltodextrin (placebo) group and the BRE group, indicating maltodextrin did not contribute to fat reduction. The placebo group showed no adverse effects, but efficacy was not the primary focus for maltodextrin.
population_specificity: Obese postmenopausal women from Korea who had stopped menstruating for over a year.

study_goal: The study aimed to examine the impact of glucosamine on gastrointestinal function, fecal microbiota, and metabolome, not Maltodextrin.
results_summary: The abstract does not mention Maltodextrin or its effects.
population_specificity: Healthy males

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of maltodextrin (placebo) versus sodium bicarbonate on blood acid-base responses and cycling performance following different warm-up intensities.
results_summary: Maltodextrin (PLA) did not significantly alter blood bicarbonate levels or cycling performance compared to sodium bicarbonate (SB), which showed marked improvements. The study found no significant effect of warm-up intensity on performance when maltodextrin was used.
population_specificity: Twelve healthy men (21 ± 2 years, 79.2 ± 3.6 kg body mass, maximum power output 318 ± 36 W).
study_duration: Single administration 3 hours prior to warm-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of resistant dextrin (RD) on satiety and glycaemic responses in healthy adults in the UK.
results_summary: RD supplementation increased fasted satiety scores and attenuated glycaemic responses but reduced post-meal satiety. It also lowered systolic blood pressure in normal-weight participants, though energy intake and anthropometrics were unaffected.
population_specificity: Healthy adults (20 normal weight and 16 overweight) living in the United Kingdom.

study_goal: The study does not address Maltodextrin; it focuses on creatine supplementation and its effects on load-velocity profile and repeated sub-maximal bouts in deep squats.
results_summary: The study does not provide any results related to Maltodextrin.
population_specificity: Eleven strength-trained men (31.4 ± 5.4 years).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine whether maltodextrin (used as a placebo) had any effect on sleep quality in individuals with mild to moderate sleep disorders associated with anxiety.
results_summary: The study found that maltodextrin did not modify sleep quality, sleep latency, sleep duration, or global scores as assessed by actigraphy and questionnaires (LSEQ and PSQI), indicating no significant effect compared to the saffron extract.
population_specificity: Subjects with mild to moderate sleep disorder associated with anxiety.
